The great difference in cost for the Space Shuttle comes from it being man-rated.  You add considerable cost when you account for research and testing, safety certification, added weight of life support, food and water, waste storage and disposal, and emergency systems, not to mention additional ground support personnel and recovery systems like the 747 transporter.  Apples and oranges when you reduce it to price per pound of payload to LEO.

While this is very exciting, I am watching this with a healthy dose of salt. All the "space tourism is just a year away!" "ultra-cheap, $100/kg launchers are due in a couple years!" was being said in 2004 when the SpaceShipOne won the X-Prize. They were claiming to be performing test space flights by late 2005, with paying customers WEEKLY by 2007. With an oribital-capable ship due a couple years after that.

And while SpaceX has done everything they've said they would, they have done it FAAAR behind their schedule. Falcon Heavy looks like it MAY have a test flight this year - it was supposed to first fly in 2014. Dragon-manned MAY have a manned flight next year. It was supposed to fly in 2015.

Even Blue Origin is way behind schedule. While other companies like Roton, Armadillo, and Almaz have either folded or at least disappeared from sight.
